A study published this week highlights that many home cooks often misjudge quantities, particularly when using traditional measuring tools. This variance can significantly impact nutritional intake, especially for those managing specific dietary requirements.

A study published this week highlights that many home cooks often misjudge quantities, particularly when using traditional measuring tools. For instance, a "katori" (small bowl) of dal might range from one hundred and fifty grams to two hundred grams depending on its depth and diameter. This variance can significantly impact nutritional intake, especially for those managing specific dietary requirements.

unnormalised: The study emphasizes the importance of using standardized measuring cups and spoons, especially for baking and precise cooking. Many Indian recipes call for ingredients in "chammach" (spoonfuls) or "mutthi" (handfuls), which are inherently inconsistent. A "tablespoon" (15 ml) of oil can easily become 20 ml if heaped, adding unnecessary calories. Similarly, using "one glass" of rice can be misleading, as glass sizes vary widely. The researchers suggest that converting to standard units of measurement, like grams or milliliters, can improve accuracy and consistency in recipes.
